item.title: Animating time series data
item.description: Introduction Packages and data Summarizing posts by month Making animations Future directions Introduction A year ago, I started playing around with the gganimate package for my interactive clothing network post. I decided to revisit the package again as I wanted to create some animated visualizations for my upcoming PhD defense (It’s partially my hope that saying that out loud will make it feel more real). To my surprise, the gganimate package has undergone a transformation in the last year under the stewardship of Thomas Pederson.

item.title: A Shiny app to find your nearest Arby's
item.description: Sometimes your inspirations for data visualizations come from strange places. I can’t say I remember how Arby’s came into a recent conversation with my friends, but someone made a joke about the restaurant chain and the thing that popped into my mind was, “I can make a Shiny app for that.” So that’s the general overview for how this post came to be.

item.title: The Best of Styleforum’s What Are You Wearing Today Thread - 2018 Edition
item.description: Introduction Data Scraping Analyzing thumbs in 2017 and 2018 Hypothesis Testing Frequentist hypothesis testing Bayesian hypothesis testing References Introduction Happy New Year! For the second year now, I’ve returned to compile the most popular pictures from Styleforum’s ‘What Are You Wearing Today (WAYWT)’ thread. As a primer if you didn’t read last year’s post, the WAYWT thread is one of the most active and popular areas on the site.

item.title: Making interview practice more effective
item.description: I’m in the middle of a job hunt for a data science position and that means lots of studying for interviews. To help me study, I’ve enlisted the help of friends and family to quiz me by ‘randomly’ selecting questions from lists. Asking them to scroll through lists though, is somewhat cumbersome and annoying. With that in mind, I wrote a small Python module that would randomly select interview questions across a number of different categories related to data science and print them one by one to the screen.

item.title: Just how good is TensorFlow at categorizing images anyways?
item.description: Introduction Okay, that title is a bit of a rhetorical question. Everyone knows that TensorFlow is great at categorizing images. For the purposes of my self-interest and curiosity though, I wanted to see the magic with my own eyes. I should say straight from the start that this post won’t contain any new code, and the overall goal is more for me to play around in the sandbox and learn more about how image classification models work (which I think is equally as fun!

item.title: Probabilistic Models for Ad Conversion Prediction
item.description: This summer I had the opportunity to do an internship in data science at the advertising technology company MediaMath. The experience was challenging, educational, and a lot of fun. My project was to investigate methods of probabilistic programming for ad conversion prediction and to deliver a viable method that could be used for production. I had the chance to write about the outcomes of my work and to be the first post in MediaMath’s new data science blog.

item.title: Mapping korean fried chicken restaurants
item.description: Introduction Data pre-processing Mapping the data Map customization Refs Introduction A change of pace! I realized that almost all of my posts thus far have been clothing related, so I decided to pivot and work with another of my interests; fried chicken. Fried chicken is irresistable, and my apartment in Boston is close to a number of korean fried chicken restaurants. For this analysis, I wanted to visualize how a specific chain of korean fried chicken restaurants, Bonchon, were distributed across the United States.

item.title: Classifying styleforum posts using a Naive Bayes approach
item.description: Introduction Text scraping Text mining Building the classifier Assessing classifier performance Referencess Introduction The ways in which people talk about clothing can vary across different sub-populations. On styleforum, the two largest sub-populations are those that are interested in classic menswear versus those that are interested in streetwear. The forum itself is actually divided into these two sides. This posed an interesting question to me to determine if differences in the way that these two sides of the forum discuss clothes could be used to classify posts.

item.title: Visualizing color frequency of clothing choices
item.description: Data Preprocessing Constructing a grid of colors Visualizing color frequencies References In a preivous post, I visualizled color choices in clothing using slope charts and histograms. This time I wanted to get a bit more creative. In this post I’m going to explore how color frequencies in my clothing choices change across months by using waffle charts. As usual, to start here’s a list of the packages that I used in this post.

item.title: Using the forcats package to easily reorder factors
item.description: Like all programmers, I strive to make my code efficient and easily readable. I hope that the results are somewhat close to those two ideals, but I know that there are always better ways to code things (this xkcd hits alarmingly close to home for me…) (source: xkcd) That being said, I’m always happy to stumble into R packages or snippets of code that can help me become more efficient in writing code and I do my best to remind myself to try and use these methods in the future.

item.title: Interactive clothing networks
item.description: This is the 3rd part of my analysis on daily clothing choices (part 1 and part 2). In this post I’m going to be testing out the the threejs package and creating interactive networks using the graphjs function. I will also be using David Robinson’s gganimate package to create an animated timeline of my clothing choices. As usual, here’s the packages used.

item.title: Sentiment analysis of fashion enthusiasts
item.description: Like most hobbyists, clothing enthusiasts tend to have strong opinions. In this post I wanted to look at how these opinions changed across time using sentiment analysis and text mining. My dataset of choice was user posts from the Saint Laurent Paris thread on Styleforum. The data was comprised of text from user posts beginning in 2012 and continuing up until today. As usual, here’s the list of packages used.

item.title: Web scraping the most popular fit pictures of 2017 from Styleforum’s “What are you wearing today” thread
item.description: One of the main draws of Styleforum is it’s “What Are You Wearing Today” thread. In it, users get to show off their clothes in pictures, other users can give “likes” to deem a fit exemplary (if you’ve ever opened up Instagram this concept is probably not too foreign for you). I wanted to see not only which posts were given the most likes in 2017, but I also wanted to download the photo(s) from each fit to upload into a photo album to share with others.

item.title: Text scraping Styleforum’s “Random Fashion Thoughts” thread
item.description: Styleforum’s “Random fashion thoughts” is one of the most popular sections of the website. It’s a thread where users can talk about almost anything they want regarding clothing and fashion. Every once in awhile the thread gets so long that the moderators opt to close it off and create a new post. The most recent iteration, RFT II, was recently retired so I decided to give myself a weekend project and run some text analysis on it.

item.title: Network analysis of my daily clothing choices
item.description: This is a continuation of my previous analysis on tracking preferences in clothing choices (part 1 is here). The inspiration for this post came about after re-reading David Robinson’s network analysis of the movie love actually and realizing that a similar approach could be applied to my sparse network of clothing choices. I found additional help by working through the Network Analysis course on Datacamp. As per usual, these were the packages used.

item.title: Tracking preferences in my daily clothing choices
item.description: Clothing is one of my hobbies. I spend a fair amount of time thinking, searching for, and talking about clothes with some of my friends. This led me to ask whether I could analyze my own clothing preferences over a period of time starting from Sept. 15 - Dec. 15th. While I’m consciously aware of some of my preferences (I wear a lot of black and clothes from Belgian born designers), I was hoping that I might see other patterns of choices that I had not picked up on.

item.title: Visualizing home states for Top Chef contestants in R
item.description: Each season of Top Chef is something that I look forward to every year and it’s one of the only shows that my girlfriend and I will make an hour of time for every week to watch. To my delight, this season two of my favorite writers Tom Haberstroh and Kevin Arnovitz have started a weekly podcast called Pack Your Knives to discuss each episode and share their love of Top Chef.
